awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of Enodia: A Highly Reconfigurable, HPC-Backed Instrument Enabling Multifaceted Interactive Visualization
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, developing a highly reconfigurable collaborative visualization instrument named Enodia, aims to support virtual reality (VR) and 2D content, and multiple interaction modalities (supporting very different physical display constellations) at the institution and within satellite nodes at several collaborating colleges and universities. Enodia operationalizes the idea that different activities call for different physical arrangements of tools, workspaces, and people for intensive research engagement with screen mediated content, especially for collaboration and communication-oriented research activities. It builds upon groundbreaking hybrid tangible multitouch and gestural interaction support and allows highly diverse room-scale display geometries to be reconfigured within minutes/seconds, flexibly driving many displays in diverse locations across several campuses (outreach partners).  It also permits its compute cluster to be back-filled at lower priority.

The approach allows for several large stage screens of the anchor visualization environment and multiscreen deployments at a flagship and several regionally and nationally distributed satellite locations (all driven by a single computer cluster) to be physically reconfigured in minutes and even seconds. These configurations include wall(s), nooks, architectural mockups, and room partitioning into multiple independent subareas, to support diverse scientific domains and use contexts. The prioritized, layered VM approach supports both local and distributed use, both of collaborative and independent nature.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Enodia MRI grant supported development of an instrument composed of an ensemble of displays and tangible interaction devices (“interaction panels” and “hextoks”).  Notable deployments outside Clemson University included at the Smithsonian National Museum of American History (ACCelerate), Artisphere, and the ACM Tangible, Embedded, and Embodied Interaction (TEI) and Intelligent User Interface (IUI) conferences.  The instrument juxtaposed arrays of “traditional” displays – sometimes wall-mounted, and sometimes mounted in custom architectural structures – with tangible “interaction panels” and “hextoks.”  Special emphasis was made iteratively designing and engineering these panels to a fashion that is economically reproducible.  E.g., the Smithsonian deployment depended extensively on two ~$400k 3D printers (one of which is no longer commercially reproducible), with panels typically at $500-$1k material&component cost.  In contrast, the modularized US interaction panel pictured is printable on entry-level consumer 3D printers, with pennies of material-cost and <$10 of electronics.  Many of the instrument elements made creative use of actuation.  E.g., the pictured MorphMatrix (presented at the ACM TEI and ACM IUI conferences) actuates 64 discrete elements with ~$100 of material and electronics (behavior that approached ~$100k several years ago, and far more previously).  We have been releasing instrument elements open-source for non-commercial use alongside accompanying academic publications (e.g., some in 2024, and others with in-press and pending publications).

 


Last Modified: 02/04/2025
Modified by: Brygg A Ullmer

    Brygg Ullmer
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)

    Installation of instrument at ACM IUI
  • This interaction panel re-implements an element from our Smithsonian deployment, there requiring ~$500 hardware with production by two $400,000 3D printers, to ~$10 hardware reproducible with entry-end consumer 3D printers. Here, partially disassembled to show LED, capacitive sensing, & computer.
    Brygg Ullmer

    Southeastern United States interaction panel
